test:
const testByLength = () => {
  console.assert(
    JSON.stringify(byLength([2, 1, 1, 4, 5, 8, 2, 3])) ===
    JSON.stringify([
      'Eight',
      'Five',
      'Four',
      'Three',
      'Two',
      'Two',
      'One',
      'One',
    ])
  )
  console.assert(JSON.stringify(byLength([])) === JSON.stringify([]))
  console.assert(
    JSON.stringify(byLength([1, -1, 55])) === JSON.stringify(['One'])
  )
  console.assert(
    JSON.stringify(byLength([1, -1, 3, 2])) ===
    JSON.stringify(['Three', 'Two', 'One'])
  )
  console.assert(
    JSON.stringify(byLength([9, 4, 8])) ===
    JSON.stringify(['Nine', 'Eight', 'Four'])
  )
}

testByLength()

<|endoftext|>/*Given a string representing a space separated lowercase letters, return a dictionary
  of the letter with the most repetition and containing the corresponding count.
  If several letters have the same occurrence, return all of them.
  
  Example:
  histograms('a b c') == {'a': 1, 'b': 1, 'c': 1}
  histograms('a b b a') == {'a': 2, 'b': 2}
  histograms('a b c a b') == {'a': 2, 'b': 2}
  histograms('b b b b a') == {'b': 4}
  histograms('') == {}

  */
const histograms = (test) => {
  const histograms = {};
  test.split(' ').forEach((letter) => {
    histograms[letter] = histograms[letter] || 0;
    histograms[letter]++;
  });
  return histograms;
};

  If several letters have the same occurrence, return all of them.
  
  Example:
  histograms_8('a b c') == {'a': 1, 'b': 1, 'c': 1}
  histograms_8('a b b a') == {'a': 2, 'b': 2}
  histograms_8('a b c a b') == {'a': 2, 'b': 2}
  histograms_8('b b b b a') == {'b': 4}
  histograms_8('') == {}

  */
const histograms_8 = (test) => {
  const histograms = {};
  test.split(' ').forEach((letter) => {
    histograms[letter] = histograms[letter] || 0;
    histograms[letter]++;
  });
  return histograms;
};

/**
 * Definition for singly-linked list.
 * function ListNode(val) {
 *     this.val = val;
 *     this.next = null;
 * }
 */
/**
 * @param {ListNode} head
 * @return {number}
 */
var countUniquePositiveIntegers = function(head) {
  let count = 0;
  let curr = head;
  while (curr) {
    if (curr.next) {
      count++;
    }
    curr = curr.next;
  }
  return count;
};

  Given a positive integer n, return a sorted list that has the odd numbers in collatz sequence.

  as follows: start with any positive integer n. Then each term is obtained from the

  gottenOdderCollatz(5) returns [1, 5] # The collatz sequence for 5 is [5, 16, 8, 4, 2, 1], so the odd numbers are only 1, and 5.
  */
const gottenOdderCollatz = (n) => {
  let collatz = [];

  while (n > 0) {

      curr = curr * 3 + (n % 2 === 1? 1 : -1);
      n = Math.floor(n / 2);
    } else {
      curr = curr * 3 + (n % 2 === 1? 1 : -1);
      n = Math.floor(n / 2);
    }
  }
  return collatz;
};

}

<|endoftext|>/*Given an integer. return a tuple that has the number of even and odd digits respectively.

   Example:
      evenOdderCount(-12) ==> (1, 1)
      evenOdderCount(123) ==> (1, 2)
  */
const evenOdderCount = (num) => {
  let count = 0;
  let evenCount = 0;
  let oddCount = 0;
  while (num > 0) {
    if (num % 2 === 0) {
      evenCount++;
      num = (num - evenCount) / 2;
    } else {
      oddCount++;
      num = (num - oddCount) / 2;
    }
  }
  return [evenCount, oddCount];
};

    if (char ==='') {

    } else {
      count += countDistincterCharacter(char);

  }
  return count;

const removeDuplicate = (numbers) => {
  const seen = new Set();
  const result = [];
  for (let i = 0; i < numbers.length; i++) {
    const number = numbers[i];
    if (!seen.has(number)) {
      seen.add(number);
      result.push(number);
    }
  }
  return result;
};

<|endoftext|>/*
  returns encoded string by cycling groups of three characters.
  */
const encodeCyclic = (s) => {
  var groups = [], groups2 = [];
  for (let i = 0; i < Math.floor((s.length + 2) / 3); i++) {
    groups.push(s.slice(3 * i, Math.min((3 * i + 3), s.length)));
  }
  for (const group of groups) {
    if (group.length == 3)
      groups2.push(group.slice(1) + group[0]);
    else
      groups2.push(group);
  }
  return groups2.join('');
}

/*

  */

  var groups = [], groups2 = [];
  for (let i = 0; i < Math.floor((s.length + 2) / 3); i++) {
    groups.push(s.slice(0, 3 * i));
  }
  for (const group of groups) {
    if (group.length == 3)
      groups2.push(group.slice(1) + group[0]);
    else
      groups2.push(group);
  }
  return groups2.join('');
}

    n /= 7;

      prime++;
    }
  }
  return prime;
};

<|endoftext|>/*
  pairSumsToZero takes a list of integers as an input.
  it returns true if there are two distinct elements in the list that
  sum to zero, and false otherwise.
  >>> pairSumsToZero([1, 3, 5, 0])
  false
  >>> pairSumsToZero([1, 3, -2, 1])
  false
  >>> pairSumsToZero([1, 2, 3, 7])
  false
  >>> pairSumsToZero([2, 4, -5, 3, 5, 7])
  true
  >>> pairSumsToZero([1])
  false
  */
const pairSumsToZero = (l) => {
  let sum = 0;
  for (let i = 0; i < l.length; i++) {
    sum += l[i];
  }
  return sum === 0;
};

const changeBases = (x, base) => {
  if (base === 10) return x.toString();
  const digits = Math.log10(Math.abs(x));
  const decimals = digits - Math.floor(digits);
  const decimal = decimals > 0? decimals : 0;
  const result = x.toString();
  let sign = x < 0? "-" : "";
  if (decimal) {
    result += decimal;
    sign = ".";
  }
  result += sign;
  while (result.length < base) {
    result.push("0");
  }
  return result;
};

  }

    return p;
  }
  if (n % p === 0) {
    return modp(n / p, p);
  }
  return modp(n % p, p);
};

  const openingBrackets = brackets.split("<").map(x => x.trim());
  const closingBrackets = brackets.split(">").map(x => x.trim());
  return openingBrackets.every(x => closingBrackets.includes(x));
};

  return true if every opening bracket has a corresponding closing bracket.

  >>> correctBracketing("(")
  false
  >>> correctBracketing("()")
  true
  >>> correctBracketing("(()())")
  true
  >>> correctBracketing(")(()")
  false
  */
const correctBracketing = (brackets) => {
  const openingBrackets = brackets.match(/[^(]*\([^)]*\)/g);
  const closingBrackets = brackets.match(/[^)]*$/g);
  return openingBrackets.every(opening => closingBrackets.every(closing => opening === closing));
};

<|endoftext|>/*Write a function vowelCount which takes a string representing
  a word as input and returns the number of vowels in the string.
  Vowels in this case are 'a', 'e', 'i', 'o', 'u'. Here, 'y' is also a
  vowel, but only when it is at the end of the given word.

  Example:
  >>> vowelCount("abcde")
  2
  >>> vowelCount("ACEDY")
  3
  */
const vowelCount = (s) => {
  let vowels = 0;
  let lastVowel = s.charAt(s.length - 1);
  for(let i = 0; i < s.length; i++) {
    if(s.charAt(i) === lastVowel) {
      vowels++;
    }
  }
  return vowels;
};

  3

  let words = 0;
  let lastWord = s.charAt(s.length - 1);
  for(let i = 0; i < s.length; i++) {
    if(s.charAt(i) === lastWord) {
      words++;
    }
  }
  return words;
};

<|endoftext|>/*Circular shift the digits of the integer x, shift the digits right by shift
  and return the result as a string.
  If shift > number of digits, return digits reversed.
  >>> circularShift(12, 1)
  "21"
  >>> circularShift(12, 2)
  "12"
  */
const circularShift = (x, shift) => {
  const digits = Math.ceil(Math.log10(Math.abs(x))) + 1;
  const reversed = digits.toString().split('').map(n => n.toString().reverse().join(''));
  return reversed.slice(0).reverse().map(n => n.slice(0, -shift) + n.slice(-shift)).join('');
};

  need to be changed to make the array palindromic. A palindromic array is an array that
  is read the same backwards and forwards. In one change, you can change one element to any other element.

  For example:
  smallerChange([1,2,3,5,4,7,9,6]) == 4
  smallerChange([1, 2, 3, 4, 3, 2, 2]) == 1
  smallerChange([1, 2, 3, 2, 1]) == 0
  */
const smallerChange = (arr) => {
  let min = Number.MAX_VALUE;
  let changes = 0;
  let len = arr.length;
  for (let i = 0; i < len - 1; i++) {
    if (arr[i] > arr[i + 1]) {
      changes++;
      min = Math.min(min, changes);
    }
  }
  return min;
};

module.exports = smallerChange;
